page.title: 03A Rutland Village
page.content: Lyddington in the old county of Rutland, became part of Leicestershire in 1974 in the boundary changes. It is a street village,of a mile in length. The houses are mainly ironstone with thatched or Collyweston slate roofs; plus a new estate of brick built houses. There is a village green with the remains of an old cross; a swing and a roundabout for children and two seats. There is 1 pub in this block, The White Hart, a free house, the Post Office and general store,Norman Church and Bede House,an historic site; 3 farms, 1 tenanted by the Church Commissioners, 2 owner occupied all with land spread around the area. Farming is mixed. Population is 360 with approximately 150 houses.The resident vicar also serves the parishes of Stoke Dry and Seaton. .
